headline.seo: Body Mass Index Can Be Misleading
headline.print_headline: Weight Index Doesn’t Tell the Whole Truth
headline.main: Weight Index Doesn’t Tell the Whole Truth

docs.lead_paragraph: Body mass index may be useful for identifying obesity in large populations, but in individuals it doesn’t differentiate between fatty and lean tissue.
docs.snippet: Body mass index may be useful for identifying obesity in large populations, but in individuals it doesn’t differentiate between fatty and lean tissue.

headline.seo: For New York Men, a 6-Year Life Expectancy Gap
headline.print_headline: LONGEVITY: For New York Men, a Life Expectancy Gap
headline.main: Longevity: For New York Men, a Life Expectancy Gap

docs.lead_paragraph: Men die about six years younger, according to a new report from the New York City health department.
docs.snippet: Men die about six years younger, according to a new report from the New York City health department.

docs.abstract: In this week's Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about why the traditional measure of a healthy weight, the body mass index, is not always reliable for determining whether someone is carrying too much fat.
docs.lead_paragraph: In this week's Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about why the traditional measure of a healthy weight, the body mass index, is not always reliable for determining whether someone is carrying too much fat. She writes:
docs.snippet: In this week's Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about why the traditional measure of a healthy weight, the body mass index, is not always reliable for determining whether someone is carrying too much fat.
